item.title: U.S. Imports Grew in 2025, as Trump’s Tariffs Reshuffled Global Trade
item.content:encoded: Data released Thursday by the Census Bureau showed the overall trade deficit with the world narrowed, the result of an expanding trade surplus in services. The trade deficit in goods was the highest on record.

item.title: U.S. Imports Grew in 2025, as Trump’s Tariffs Reshuffled Global Trade
item.content:encoded: Data released Thursday by the Census Bureau showed the overall trade deficit with the world narrowed, the result of an expanding trade surplus in services. The trade deficit in goods was the highest on record.

item.title: Who Would Win Gold in the Coward Olympics?
item.content:encoded: There are a lot of potential contestants.

item.title: New York to Back Away From Robotaxi Pilot Programs Upstate
item.content:encoded: Gov. Kathy Hochul had proposed expanding the programs beyond New York City, but they do not have enough support, her office said.

item.title: Our Favorite, Most Outrageous and Most Unexpected Moments of the Games
item.content:encoded: Three writers and an Olympic medalist on the grit and grace of the winter games.

item.title: Gaza’s Board of Peace: What to Know
item.content:encoded: President Trump’s new organization was established to oversee a Gaza cease-fire but has expanded its mandate. Critics say it could undermine the United Nations.

item.title: Trump Mulls a North American Trade Pact Without Canada
item.content:encoded: U.S. officials are threatening major changes to a trade agreement with Mexico and Canada that could upend the way business is done and leave Canada on the outs.

item.title: Trump Mulls a North American Trade Pact Without Canada
item.content:encoded: U.S. officials are threatening major changes to a trade agreement with Mexico and Canada that could upend the way business is done and leave Canada on the outs.

item.title: A Swiss Survivor on What It’s Like to Be Caught in an Avalanche
item.content:encoded: Heinz Mueller was buried under 30 feet of snow in the Swiss Alps in 1993 but made it out alive. “It’s panic,” he says.

item.title: Assault on Sudanese City Bore ‘Hallmarks of Genocide,’ U.N. Finds
item.content:encoded: A paramilitary group in Sudan’s civil war “acted with genocidal intent” in a monthslong siege of El Fasher, according to human rights experts.

item.title: Walmart Expects Growth Streak to Continue as New Chief Takes Over
item.content:encoded: Shoppers are turning to Walmart to stretch their dollars, but an uncertain economy and trade tensions will test the retailer’s new executive team.

item.title: Sugar Bowl Academy Says Multiple Victims Were Tied to Its Ski Resort School
item.content:encoded: Many of the people on the fatal trek had ties to a ski-focused private school, Sugar Bowl Academy, in the Sierra Nevada.

item.title: An A.I. Fight at the Pentagon, and Former Prince Andrew Is Arrested Over Epstein Ties
item.content:encoded: Plus, a lifesaving phone feature.

item.title: After Avalanche Warnings, a Sierra Nevada Tragedy
item.content:encoded: Eight skiers were killed and one other was presumed dead in the deadliest snow disaster in modern California history. Six were found alive.

item.title: Jittery Markets Seek an Iran ‘Off-Ramp’
item.content:encoded: Oil prices spiked and stocks fell as tensions between Washington and Tehran unnerved investors.

item.title: Where Things Stand on Witkoff and Kushner’s Negotiations Over Iran, Ukraine and Gaza
item.content:encoded: Iran, Ukraine and Gaza are in play as the Trump envoys conduct talks on all of them. But progress in each conflict is scant.

item.title: Dueling Protests at South Korean Ex-Leader’s Sentencing Highlight Political Rift
item.content:encoded: As a judge reprimanded former President Yoon Suk Yeol for amplifying political tribalism, demonstrators from warring camps blared slogans outside the courtroom.

item.title: The Board of Peace
item.content:encoded: Today we look at President Trump’s new diplomatic initiative.

item.title: Europe Worries About Another Trump Blowup, This One on Tech
item.content:encoded: Even as trade tensions between the United States and the European Union seem to calm, officials are concerned that a showdown is brewing over the bloc’s digital rules.

item.title: In Devastated Gaza, Grandiose Peace Plans Clash With Reality
item.content:encoded: Israeli strikes on Gaza have killed about 600 people since a cease-fire began, according to health officials in the territory. Many displaced Palestinians are still living in tents. And there are some 60 million tons of war debris to be cleared.

item.title: In Lake Tahoe Avalanche Recovery, the Safety of Searchers Is Top Concern
item.content:encoded: Weather and snow conditions will dictate when the bodies of skiers killed in the avalanche near Lake Tahoe can be retrieved from mountain. More snow is expected.

item.title: How Trump Is Making Sure His Ballroom Plans Sail Through
item.content:encoded: President Trump has installed allies — including his former receptionist — on the boards and commissions tasked with overseeing the project.

item.title: Uber Moves to Enact Stricter Background Checks for Drivers
item.content:encoded: The New York Times revealed in December that the ride-hailing giant approved drivers with many types of criminal convictions, including violent felonies.

item.title: Ring’s Founder Knows You Hated That Super Bowl Ad
item.content:encoded: Since the commercial aired, Jamie Siminoff has been trying to quell an outcry over privacy concerns with his doorbell cameras.

item.title: Ring’s Founder Knows You Hated That Super Bowl Ad
item.content:encoded: Since the commercial aired, Jamie Siminoff has been trying to quell an outcry over privacy concerns with his doorbell cameras.

item.title: Lively v. Baldoni Tests What Crosses the Line on a ‘Steamy’ Movie Set
item.content:encoded: An affectionate slow dance. References to pornography. What rises to harassment on the set of a movie about a sexual relationship that turns violent?

item.title: Billy Idol Had It All, and Then He ‘Lit It With Butane’
item.content:encoded: Last year, the British rocker with the iconic sneer played his biggest tour yet. At 70, he’s revealing how he survived the tough times in a new documentary.

item.title: University of British Columbia Professors Sue School Over Political Correctness
item.content:encoded: A group of academics at the University of British Columbia say the school’s D.E.I. policies and practices, which include land acknowledgments, violate a law that requires universities to be “nonpolitical.”

item.title: Alysa Liu Is Skating Again, Her Way This Time
item.content:encoded: At 16, out of love with the sport, Liu stepped away. Controlling her career, after years of oversight from her father, was the only way she could return.

item.title: Money Talks as India Searches for Its Place in Global A.I.
item.content:encoded: Narendra Modi, the prime minister, convened foreign leaders, the richest Silicon Valley companies and thousands of Indian entrepreneurs for a week of deal making.

item.title: Stephen Colbert Sizes Up R.F.K. Jr.’s Workout With Kid Rock
item.content:encoded: “The Late Show” host called the 90-second video of the two working up a sweat together “pure cinema.”

item.title: Russia Celebrated Him. Now He’s Accused of Having Troops Shoot Themselves.
item.content:encoded: A lieutenant colonel is on trial after being accused of skimming payments for battlefield injuries. He denies the specifics of Russia’s accusation but acknowledges engaging in a payouts scheme.

item.title: Stock Slide and Slow Sales: What’s Happening in China’s E.V. Market?
item.content:encoded: Investors are selling shares of Chinese E.V. companies, concerned that intensifying competition and shorter production cycles mean the years of easy growth are over.

item.title: Stock Slide and Slow Sales: What’s Happening in China’s E.V. Market?
item.content:encoded: Investors are selling shares of Chinese E.V. companies, concerned that intensifying competition and shorter production cycles mean the years of easy growth are over.

item.title: As Trump Weighs Possible Iran Strikes, U.S. Military Moves Into Place
item.content:encoded: President Trump has given no indication that he has made a decision about how to proceed, as diplomatic talks continue.

item.title: Maps: Where the U.S. Is Building Up Military Force Near Iran
item.content:encoded: President Trump has not authorized military action in Iran, but the United States has built up its presence in the region in recent weeks. Now it’s sending even more firepower.

item.title: How Mamdani’s Income and Property Tax Proposals Could Affect New Yorkers
item.content:encoded: Mayor Zohran Mamdani has now proposed two options that called for raising taxes. Here’s a look at each proposal and the rationale and chances for each.

item.title: Defense Department and Anthropic Square Off in Dispute Over A.I. Safety
item.content:encoded: How artificial intelligence will be used in future battlefields is an issue that has turned increasingly political and may put Anthropic in a bind.

item.title: Defense Department and Anthropic Square Off in Dispute Over A.I. Safety
item.content:encoded: How artificial intelligence will be used in future battlefields is an issue that has turned increasingly political and may put Anthropic in a bind.

item.title: The Sleepy Market for Japanese Government Bonds Is Now a ‘Battlefield’
item.content:encoded: Trading of Japanese government bonds, long considered moribund, is roaring back to life as fears of the country’s debt have sent yields surging.

item.title: Workplace Inspections by OSHA Dropped Over a Six-Month Period of 2025
item.content:encoded: Labor advocates worry that the Trump administration is relaxing oversight of companies and increasing the potential for serious injuries and deaths.

item.title: Donald J. Trump International Airport? The President’s Company Trademarked It.
item.content:encoded: The Trump organization said the move was necessary to protect the brand as Florida prepares to rename an airport after the president.

item.title: F.D.A. Reverses Decision and Agrees to Review Moderna’s Flu Vaccine
item.content:encoded: Moderna held further discussions with regulators and announced that the agency would accept the company’s application for approval of its flu vaccine that uses mRNA technology.

item.title: Etsy Sells Depop, a Secondhand Clothing App Popular With Gen Z, to eBay
item.content:encoded: The $1.2 billion deal comes as eBay looks to expand its appeal among younger users.

item.title: Edison Will Reduce Executive Bonuses as a Result of the Eaton Fire
item.content:encoded: Southern California Edison had said its electrical equipment most likely caused the blaze, which destroyed much of Altadena, a Los Angeles suburb.

item.title: The New York Times Wins 3 Polk Awards
item.content:encoded: The Times was honored for its coverage of President Trump, the abuse of housekeepers and nannies in Saudi Arabia and brutality in New York prisons.

item.title: Fed Minutes Show No Rush to Restart Rate Cuts
item.content:encoded: Barring a rapid deterioration in the labor market or a significant cooling of inflation, the Federal Reserve appears poised for an extended hold.

item.title: What Do A.I. Chatbots Discuss Among Themselves? We Sent One to Find Out.
item.content:encoded: We interviewed our bot about what it learned on Moltbook, the A.I.-only social network.

item.title: From 2001: Rose Freedman, Last Survivor of Triangle Fire, Dies at 107
item.content:encoded: She escaped the Triangle Shirtwaist fire of 1911, in which 146 of her co-workers perished, and dedicated the rest of her life to worker safety.

item.title: Kentucky Derby Operator Accused of Regulatory ‘Freeloading’
item.content:encoded: The Horseracing Integrity and Safety Authority filed a complaint saying Churchill Downs Inc. is not paying its fair share to support inspections and testing.

item.title: Elon Musk’s xAI Gets $3 Billion Investment From Saudi-Backed A.I. Firm
item.content:encoded: Humain, which was created by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman last year, said it made the investment just before xAI was acquired by SpaceX, Mr. Musk’s rocket company.

item.title: How Crypto’s Lobbying Muscle May Save the Clarity Act
item.content:encoded: A market rout may have decimated the crypto industry. But its machine in Washington may power proposed regulation past concerned Democrats.

item.title: Uber Taking Steps to Expand Number of EV Chargers Near Its Drivers
item.content:encoded: The company said it would encourage companies that operated chargers to install them in neighborhoods where its drivers lived and work.

item.title: Trump Hails Japan’s First Batch of U.S. Investments
item.content:encoded: The deals, totaling $36 billion, were the first step in a $550 billion investment pledge aimed at securing tariff relief and sustaining U.S. relations.

item.title: Boneless Wings Are Still Wings, Judge Rules
item.content:encoded: A Chicago man filed a lawsuit in 2023 against Buffalo Wild Wings, arguing that it had engaged in false advertising of its boneless wings. A judge said the claim “has no meat on its bones.”

item.title: Goldman Sachs to Drop D.E.I. Criteria for Board Members
item.content:encoded: The move would be the Wall Street firm’s latest retreat from diversity mandates that its chief executive, David Solomon, had once made a priority.

item.title: White House Shrugs Off Lutnick’s Epstein Ties
item.content:encoded: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick has acknowledged traveling to Jeffrey Epstein’s island and meeting him on another occasion.

item.title: Are you a medical provider who has worked in an ICE detention facility? We want to hear from you.
item.content:encoded: We want to get a better picture of what medical care for immigrants in detention is like.

item.title: Colbert Slams Trump Administration After CBS Pulls Talarico Interview
item.content:encoded: Stephen Colbert said he had to drop an interview with James Talarico from his Monday broadcast because of new F.C.C. guidance that targeted political interviews on late-night shows.

item.title: Bayer Agrees to Pay $7.25 Billion to Settle Roundup Lawsuits
item.content:encoded: The agreement, which still faces legal hurdles, would cover current and future claims that the weedkiller caused non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

item.title: Warner Bros. Discovery Restarts Deal Talks With Paramount
item.content:encoded: Paramount’s takeover bid was rejected in favor of Netflix, which wanted only the streaming and studio businesses. Paramount said it would pay more if negotiations were reopened.

item.title: Anderson Cooper Is Leaving ’60 Minutes’
item.content:encoded: Mr. Cooper said in a statement that he was leaving as a correspondent for the show to focus on his CNN program and spend more time with his children.

item.title: GQ Names Adam Baidawi as Its Top Editor
item.content:encoded: Mr. Baidawi, 35, replaces the magazine’s longtime editor Will Welch. He says he wants the magazine to be a “North Star of masculinity.”

item.title: Vaccine Makers Curtail Research and Cut Jobs
item.content:encoded: Federal policies under Robert F. Kennedy Jr. that are hostile to vaccines have “sent a chill through the entire industry,” one scientist said.

item.title: Should Drug Companies Be Advertising to Consumers?
item.content:encoded: Aging means “becoming a target” of the industry, one expert said. After decades of debate, politicians of all stripes are proposing bans.

item.title: Paramount’s New Chance to Win Over Warner Bros. Discovery
item.content:encoded: The takeover battle took a new turn on Tuesday as Warner Bros. Discovery reopened talks with its rebuffed suitor. But big questions still remain.

item.title: Trump Sought Vast Budget Cuts. Congress Granted Few.
item.content:encoded: In a series of deals over the past three months, lawmakers rejected some of the president’s most aggressive attempts to whittle down the government.

item.title: With Niche Tech World References, Vibe Hopes Its Billboards Reach Start-Up Insiders
item.content:encoded: Billboards that wouldn’t make sense to people outside the tech industry have become common in the Bay Area. One company took the microtargeting game to another level.

item.title: How the H-1B Visa Debate Is Driving a Wave of Racism Against South Asians
item.content:encoded: A dispute over the impact of H-1B visas on U.S. workers has been overshadowed by racist rhetoric, with troubling echoes of the great replacement conspiracy theory.

item.title: Warner Bros. Is Said to Consider Reopening Talks With Paramount
item.content:encoded: Warner Bros. Discovery had agreed to sell itself to Netflix, but its contract allows it to pursue offers that may lead to a superior deal.

item.title: The Quiet Architect of Trump’s Global Trade War
item.content:encoded: Jamieson Greer, a low-key lawyer from a working-class background, is rewriting the rules of the global economy at the president’s behest.

item.title: How a Trump Tax Break Rescued Horse Racing
item.content:encoded: Owners spent nearly $1.5 billion last year on racehorses, a big increase over 2024. A new tax provision allows them to immediately deduct the full cost of the purchase.

item.title: Diplomatic Feud With China Weighs on Japan’s Economy
item.content:encoded: A standoff over the security of Taiwan has led to a steep decline in the number of Chinese visitors to Japan, which is heavily dependent on the tourists.

item.title: Trump Administration Ends Credit for Start-Stop Feature in Cars
item.content:encoded: Manufacturers will no longer get a credit toward vehicle emissions standards by installing engines that automatically stop at red lights.

item.title: Like Trump, U.S. Embassies Are Raising Cash for Lavish July Fourth Parties
item.content:encoded: Some of Washington’s diplomatic outposts in Asia are raising millions for events to mark the 250th independence anniversary. One ambassador offered to sing and dance.

item.title: ‘Wuthering Heights’ Gallops Toward $82 Million in Global Ticket Sales
item.content:encoded: Warner Bros. spent an estimated $80 million on the R-rated romance, directed by Emerald Fennell, not including hefty marketing costs.

item.title: Will 2026 Be the Year of the ‘Soonicorn’?
item.content:encoded: As venture capital funding pours into start-ups large and small, more firms are pitching themselves as the next big thing.

item.title: What C.E.O.s Are Worried About
item.content:encoded: Fractured politics, disruptive technologies and a distrust in institutions are making it harder to focus on the traditional tasks of growing sales and profits.

item.title: Ring Ends Deal to Link Neighborhood Cameras After Backlash to Super Bowl Ad
item.content:encoded: A commercial about a lost dog being reunited with his family ignited concerns that a “Search Party” feature posed privacy risks. Ring parted ways with the tech company Flock Safety.

item.title: How The Times Is Digging Into Millions of Pages of Epstein Files
item.content:encoded: Two dozen journalists. A pile of pages that would reach the top of the Empire State Building. And an effort to find the next revelation in a sprawling case.

item.title: The Epstein Files and the Hidden World of an Unaccountable Elite
item.content:encoded: The search continues in the documents for ironclad criminal conduct, but the story of a sexual predator given a free ride by the ruling class has already emerged.
